title: Definitions
context: §466J-1 Definitions. As used in this chapter: &ldquo;Approved school for radiologic technologists&rdquo;, &ldquo;approved training program for radiographers&rdquo;, &ldquo;approved training program for radiation therapists&rdquo;, and &ldquo;approved training program for nuclear medicine technologists&rdquo; mean a school or training program determined by the board to provide a course of instruction in radiologic technology that is adequate to meet the purposes of this chapter. &ldquo;Board&rdquo; means the radiologic technology board. &ldquo;Certified&rdquo; means holding a license issued by the board when used in conjunction with the title &ldquo;radiographer&rdquo;, &ldquo;radiation therapist&rdquo;, or &ldquo;nuclear medicine technologist&rdquo;. &ldquo;Department&rdquo; means the department of health. &ldquo;Director&rdquo; means the director of health. &ldquo;Nuclear medicine technologist&rdquo; means any person who administers radiopharmaceuticals to human beings and conducts in vivo or in vitro detection and measurement of radioactivity for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes. &ldquo;Nuclear medicine technology&rdquo; means the application of radiopharmaceuticals to human beings and the performance of in vivo or in vitro detection and measurement of radioactivity for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes. &ldquo;Radiation therapist&rdquo; means any person who applies ionizing radiation to human beings for therapeutic purposes. &ldquo;Radiation therapy technology&rdquo; means the application of ionizing radiation to human beings for therapeutic purposes. &ldquo;Radiographer&rdquo; means any person who applies x-rays to human beings for diagnostic purposes. &ldquo;Radiography&rdquo; means the application of x-rays to human beings for diagnostic purposes. &ldquo;Radiologic technologist&rdquo; means any person who applies x-rays to human beings for diagnostic purposes, ionizing radiation to human beings for therapeutic purposes, or radiopharmaceuticals for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes. &ldquo;Radiologic technology&rdquo; means the application of x-rays to human beings for diagnostic purposes, ionizing radiation to human beings for therapeutic purposes, or radiopharmaceuticals for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes. &ldquo;Supervision&rdquo; means responsibility for, and control of, quality, radiation safety, and technical aspects of all x-ray, radiopharmaceutical, or ionizing radiation examinations and procedures. [L 1974, c 253, pt of §2; am L 1980, c 128, pt of §1; am L 1990, c 273, §4; am L 1995, c 143, §2]
